elements.content: This work reported an unpresented rare-earth-ion bearing metal–organic framework (MOF) Y10(C8H4O4)6(CO3)3(OH)12 built of inorganic slabs as structural units. Eu3+ has been introduced into the lattice of Y10(C8H4O4)6(CO3)3(OH)12 to make it optically active. Systematical structural analysis combined with single crystal X-ray diffraction demonstrates Eu3+ was incorporated into the lattice of Y10(C8H4O4)6(CO3)3(OH)12 endowing the MOF with promising optical activity. Even though there was a trace amount of Eu3+ < 1%, this compound displayed excellent luminescent activity with quantum efficiency reaching up to 69%, benefiting from the inorganic circumstance of Y3+/Eu3+ in layered structure. The concentration-dependent electronic transition character of Eu3+ is systematically studied, according to Judd–Ofelt theory normally applicable in inorganic compounds. The phase analysis and optical spectroscopy study result reveal that the local crystallographic circumstance of the rare-earth metal ion basically remained inactive after the replacement of Y3+ by Eu3+. Benefiting from this rigid structure, such Eu3+-substituted Y10(C8H4O4)6(CO3)3(OH)12 powder exhibits good luminescence probing ability toward Fe3+ ion, displaying a limit detection concentration of Fe3+ down to 12.7 μM in aqueous solution. The findings here confirm Eu3+ is not only an environmental probing ion but could also serve an ideal indicator for investigating the structure change and properties of luminescent MOFs for diverse applications.

elements.content: A new layered metal−organic framework compound Y10(C8H4O4)6(CO3)3(OH)12 is reported. The optical spectroscopy and electronic transition dynamics have been studied. The Judd−Ofelt theory was utilized to calculate the electronic transition parameters. The Y3+/Eu3+ containing slab makes this compound an outstanding luminescent material with quantum efficiency as high as 69%. This compound exhibits good luminescence probing ability on Fe3+ ion.

The Y3+/Eu3+ containing slab makes this compound an outstanding luminescent material with quantum efficiency as high as 69%. This compound exhibits good luminescence probing ability on Fe3+ ion.

elements.content: In recent years along with the rapid development of laser diode (LD) and blue light emitting diode (LED), the Eu3+-containing metal–organic framework compound (MOFs)-based luminescent materials have been gaining intensive research interest because of the small-size and high power density of the pumping source enabling the device miniaturization and compactness. Visible light emitting and luminescence probe are two important applications of the Eu3+-containing luminescent MOFs, for which the luminescent quantum efficiency is an important figure of merit. The luminescent quantum efficiency, which is defined by the ratio of radiative transition probability versus the total transition probability, could be calculated according to η = A T /(A T + A N ), where A T is radiative transition probability and A N is nonradiative transition probability. Suppressing the probability of nonradiative transition caused by phonon-assist relaxation, excited state absorption, cross-relaxation or energy transfer between adjacent centers is the key to improve the luminescent quantum efficiency. For a self-quenching system, the phonon-assisted relaxation and energy transfer between adjacent centers are dominant contributors to the nonradiative transition of Eu3+ ion. The lattice vibration of the host MOF crystal is the origin of phonon-assisted relaxation of active centers. The more the vibration modes, the higher the possibility of phonon-assisted relaxation. However, the energy transfer between adjacent active centers is controlled by the distance between adjacent centers. The possibility of energy transfer between them becomes higher when they are closer to each other since the spatial overlap of electronic cloud becomes easier. So, optically active rare earth ions Eu3+, Tb3+, Sm3+, or Dy3+ are usually introduced into nonluminescent MOFs to form a heterometal–organic framework, rendering the latter good fluorescence since the distance between adjacent active centers could be controlled by tuning their concentration in the host crystal. Hence, to explore an optically active MOFs matrix with limit possibility of nonradiative transition is an unchanging pursuit in the field of optoelectronic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years along with the rapid development of laser diode (LD) and blue light emitting diode (LED), the Eu3+-containing metal-organic framework compound (MOFs)-based luminescent materials have been gaining intensive research interest because of the small-size and high power density of the pumping source enabling the device miniaturization and compactness. Visible light emitting and luminescence probe are two important applications of the Eu3+-containing luminescent MOFs, for which the luminescent quantum efficiency is an important figure of merit. The luminescent quantum efficiency, which is defined by the ratio of radiative transition probability versus the total transition probability, could be calculated according to η = A  T /(A  T  + A  N ), where A  T  is radiative transition probability and A  N  is nonradiative transition probability. Suppressing the probability of nonradiative transition caused by phonon-assist relaxation, excited state absorption, cross-relaxation or energy transfer between adjacent centers is the key to improve the luminescent quantum efficiency. For a self-quenching system, the phonon-assisted relaxation and energy transfer between adjacent centers are dominant contributors to the nonradiative transition of Eu3+ ion. The lattice vibration of the host MOF crystal is the origin of phonon-assisted relaxation of active centers. The more the vibration modes, the higher the possibility of phonon-assisted relaxation. However, the energy transfer between adjacent active centers is controlled by the distance between adjacent centers. The possibility of energy transfer between them becomes higher when they are closer to each other since the spatial overlap of electronic cloud becomes easier. So, optically active rare earth ions Eu3+, Tb3+, Sm3+, or Dy3+ are usually introduced into nonluminescent MOFs to form a heterometal-organic framework, rendering the latter good fluorescence since the distance between adjacent active centers could be controlled by tuning their concentration in the host crystal. Hence, to explore an optically active MOFs matrix with limit possibility of nonradiative transition is an unchanging pursuit in the field of optoelectronic materials.

elements.content: Because of the versatile structural arrangements and functional groups or active lattice sites, MOF compounds have been attracting intensive attention in the fields of catalysis, gas separation, light emitting, luminescence probe, and so on, whereas, the variety of vibration mode of crystal lattice plus local functional groups, hydroxyl, carboxyl, or Lewis acid/base site, to name a few, also affect the electronic transition of active centers, leading to a reduction of luminescent quantum efficiency. Therefore, to design MOF compounds with rigid structure and limit local functional groups is a promising approach to improve the quantum efficiency of active centers in it. Serial MOFs with rod-shaped building blocks and rare earth ions as the metal center have been investigated by Prof. Omar M. Yaghi and co-workers, whose work shows that MOFs with rod building blocks can be designed to have not only permanent porosity but also rigid structural framework. The excellent luminescent property and porous structure give these MOFs outstanding anion probing and gas adsorption abilities. Besides the rod building block, a complex layer with metal cluster as basic unit is an alternative approach to construct a rigid three-dimensional (3D) structure. MOF-5 is the first reported rigid 3D MOFs, the structure of which remains stable when fully desolvated and when heated up to 300 °C. A MOF compound that contains 2D parallel interpenetrating layer and Co2+ as metal center was synthesized by E. B. Wang using 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate as organic spacer, giving both the large porous network and the undulated structural features in an individual layer. H. Kitagawa and co-workers have demonstrated the promotion in proton conductivity under ambient conditions by employing a series of MOFs also with layered structure. A MOF compound with two-dimensional (2D) network and good fluorescence was synthesized by S. L. Qiu and co-workers, using Cd­(phen)2(NO3)2 as the metal source and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid as organic ligand. Layered MOFs containing lanthanide ion (Ln3+) have also been intensively studied because of the versatile coordination of Ln3+ and special electronic configuration resulting in interesting optical and magnetic features. Serial Ln3+-containing MOFs with 3D layered structure have been prepared using Eu3+ or Gd3+ as metal centers and a mixture of methylmalonic acid and isonicotinic acid as organic ligand, showing obvious optical luminescence (Eu3+-MOFs) or ferromagnetism (Gd3+-MOFs). C. Serre and co-workers also reported a series of Ln3+ containing 3D rigid MOFs with inorganic chain or metal cluster as the basic structure unit. The chains or metal clusters connect with each other by organic ligands. Some of these MOFs compounds (MIL-92 as representative) are optically functionalized by introduction of Eu3+ and exhibits excellent photoluminescence under excitation of ultraviolet light. However, Ln3+-containing rigid MOFs with inorganic slab as the structural unit have rarely been reported up to now.

elements.content: In this Article, we report the synthesis and luminescence probing property of a 3D layered MOF, Y10(C8H4O4)6(CO3)3(OH)12(MOF-1), with a structure comprising dense inorganic slabs. Eu3+ has been introduced into the lattice of this compound to make it an excellent luminescent material. The optical excitation, photoluminescence, and electronic transition dynamics have been systematically studied, during which the Judd–Ofelt theory was utilized to calculate the electronic transition parameters such as radiative transition rate, luminescence branching ratio, quantum efficiency, and quantum transition intensity parameters. Benefiting from the inorganic coordination environment, Eu3+ ion in the dense inorganic slabs in MOF-1 exhibits strong optical emission with inner quantum efficiency as high as 69% when the substitution rate of Eu3+ is 1%. Besides the good light emitting, Eu3+-substituted MOF-1 (MOF-1: Eu3+) powders also show good luminescence probing ability to detect Fe3+ ion in aqueous solution with a value of limit of detection of 12.7 μM. The possible luminescence probing mechanism has been discussed.

elements.content: Yttrium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (YCl3·6H2O, ≥99.99%), europium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (EuCl3·6H2O, ≥99.99%), and 1,4-dicarboxybenzene (H2BDC, ≥99%) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, ≥99.5%) was purchased from Xilong Chemical Engineering Co., Ltd. Gadolinium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (GdCl3·6H2O, ≥99.99%) was purchased from Tianjin Fengyue Chemical Co., Ltd. Acetic acid sodium salt trihydrate (NaAc·3H2O, ≥99%) was purchased from Hengxing Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. A mixture of YCl3·6H2O (0.300 g, 1 mmol), NaAc·3H2O (0.204 g, 1.5 mmol), and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol) were added into the mixed solvent containing H2O (10 mL) and DMF (10 mL) and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Then, the mixture was transferred into a 25 mL autoclave with a stainless-steel cover and a Teflon liner to perform solvothermal reaction at 190 °C for 120 h, after which the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature in the furnace. Colorless hexagonal-plate-like crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.1919 g (85.91% based on Y). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for compound MOF-1: Y10C51O45H12 (2233.69), C 27.42, H 0.54; found, C 26.94, H 0.54. The Eu3+-substituted compound (MOF-1:Eu3+) was prepared according to the procedure described above, using EuCl3·6H2O as source of Eu3+ to partially replace Y3+ ion. Colorless hexagonal-plates-like crystals were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Yttrium(III) chloride hexahydrate (YCl3⋅6H2O, ≥99.99%), europium(III) chloride hexahydrate (EuCl3⋅6H2O, ≥99.99%), and 1,4-dicarboxybenzene (H2BDC, ≥99%) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, ≥99.5%) was purchased from Xilong Chemical Engineering Co., Ltd. Gadolinium(III) chloride hexahydrate (GdCl3⋅6H2O, ≥99.99%) was purchased from Tianjin Fengyue Chemical Co., Ltd. Acetic acid sodium salt trihydrate (NaAc⋅3H2O, ≥99%) was purchased from Hengxing Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. A mixture of YCl3⋅6H2O (0.300 g, 1 mmol), NaAc⋅3H2O (0.204 g, 1.5 mmol), and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol) were added into the mixed solvent containing H2O (10 mL) and DMF (10 mL) and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Then, the mixture was transferred into a 25 mL autoclave with a stainless-steel cover and a Teflon liner to perform solvothermal reaction at 190 °C for 120 h, after which the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature in the furnace. Colorless hexagonal-plate-like crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.1919 g (85.91% based on Y). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for compound MOF-1: Y10C51O45H12 (2233.69), C 27.42, H 0.54; found, C 26.94, H 0.54. The Eu3+-substituted compound (MOF-1:Eu3+) was prepared according to the procedure described above, using EuCl3⋅6H2O as source of Eu3+ to partially replace Y3+ ion. Colorless hexagonal-plates-like crystals were obtained.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded on a Thermal Analysis Instrument (STA449-F5 Jupiter, Netzsch, Germany) from room temperature to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under air atmosphere. Under air atmosphere, the compound lost weight rapidly at 400 °C because of the decomposition and departure of the organic and hydroxy groups. According to Figure S1, the remaining weight of 51.6% corresponds to the percentage of the Y and O component, Ln2O3 (calculated: 50.5%). Powder XRD diffraction measurement was carried out on a Rigaku MiniFlex 600 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα line (λ = 1.54178 Å) as the incident beam. The sample powder was loaded on a glass holder and leveled with a glass slide before mounting it on the sample chamber. The inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, iCAP 7400 ICP-OES, Thermo Fisher Scientific) was employed to analyze the contents of metallic ions. Fourier transform infrared spectrum (KBr pellets) of compound MOF-1 was recorded using a BRUKER ALPHA FT-IR spectrometer. As shown in Figure S2, the displayed FT-IR spectrum of compound MOF-1 is dominated by bands stemming from the vibration of 1,4-BDC ligands and the CC stretching vibration in benzene, proving the establishment of the metal–organic framework. The peak appearing at 1402 cm–1 is assigned to the symmetric telescopic vibration peak of carboxyl among organic ligands. The vibration of ν­(CC) of the benzene ring leads to the peaks standing out at 1554 and 1619 cm–1. The characteristic peak of benzene ring para-disubstituted is observed at 823 cm–1. The peaks at 800–400 cm–1 correspond to the bending vibration peak of carboxyl in and out of the plane. The deformation vibration of the Y–O bond may account for the peak at 528 cm–1. The ν­(O–H) of MOF-1 is located at 3426 cm–1.

Characterization

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were recorded on a Thermal Analysis Instrument (STA449-F5 Jupiter, Netzsch, Germany) from room temperature to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under air atmosphere. Under air atmosphere, the compound lost weight rapidly at 400 °C because of the decomposition and departure of the organic and hydroxy groups. According to Figure S1, the remaining weight of 51.6% corresponds to the percentage of the Y and O component, Ln2O3 (calculated: 50.5%). Powder XRD diffraction measurement was carried out on a Rigaku MiniFlex 600 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα line (λ = 1.54178 Å) as the incident beam. The sample powder was loaded on a glass holder and leveled with a glass slide before mounting it on the sample chamber. The inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, iCAP 7400 ICP-OES, Thermo Fisher Scientific) was employed to analyze the contents of metallic ions. Fourier transform infrared spectrum (KBr pellets) of compound MOF-1 was recorded using a BRUKER ALPHA FT-IR spectrometer. As shown in Figure S2, the displayed FT-IR spectrum of compound MOF-1 is dominated by bands stemming from the vibration of 1,4-BDC ligands and the CC stretching vibration in benzene, proving the establishment of the metal-organic framework. The peak appearing at 1402 cm-1 is assigned to the symmetric telescopic vibration peak of carboxyl among organic ligands. The vibration of ν(CC) of the benzene ring leads to the peaks standing out at 1554 and 1619 cm-1. The characteristic peak of benzene ring para-disubstituted is observed at 823 cm-1. The peaks at 800-400 cm-1 correspond to the bending vibration peak of carboxyl in and out of the plane. The deformation vibration of the Y-O bond may account for the peak at 528 cm-1. The ν(O-H) of MOF-1 is located at 3426 cm-1.

elements.content: A colorless hexagonal plate of MOF-1 crystal with dimensions of 0.0275 × 0.0275 × 0.01 mm3 was selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The diffraction data were collected on an Agilent Technologies SuperNova Dual Wavelength CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The diffraction data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by multiscan method. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 using the SHELX-97 program package. All atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The structure was also checked for possible missing symmetry with PLATON. Crystallographic data and structural refinements are summarized in . Generally, the compound MOF-1, empirically formulated by structural determination as Y10(C8H4O4)6(CO3)3(OH)12, crystallizes in a trigonal system with space group P3c1 and lattice parameters a = b = 12.8178(12) Å, c = 21.520(2) Å. The calculated density is 2.449 g/cm3. The solution results are listed in . CCDC 1901919 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal Structure Determination

A colorless hexagonal plate of MOF-1 crystal with dimensions of 0.0275 × 0.0275 × 0.01 mm3 was selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The diffraction data were collected on an Agilent Technologies SuperNova Dual Wavelength CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The diffraction data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by multiscan method. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F  2  using the SHELX-97 program package. All atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The structure was also checked for possible missing symmetry with PLATON. Crystallographic data and structural refinements are summarized in . Generally, the compound MOF-1, empirically formulated by structural determination as Y10(C8H4O4)6(CO3)3(OH)12, crystallizes in a trigonal system with space group P3c1 and lattice parameters a = b = 12.8178(12) Å, c = 21.520(2) Å. The calculated density is 2.449 g/cm3. The solution results are listed in . CCDC 1901919 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Photoluminescence (PL) emission and excitation spectra were recorded using a Horiba FluoroMax-4 spectrophotometer equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. While measuring the spectra, both the excitation and emission splits were set at 0.6 nm; the working voltage of the photomultiplier tube was 700 V. The luminescent decay curves were recorded using a customized ultraviolet (UV) to mid-infrared steady-state laser and a phosphorescence lifetime spectrometer (FSP920-C, Edinburgh) equipped with a digital oscilloscope (TDS3052B, Tektronix) and a tunable midband optical parametric oscillator (OPO) pulse laser as the excitation source (410–2400 nm, 10 Hz, pulse width of 5 ns, Vibrant 355II, OPOTEK). The optical excitation and emission spectra of serial MOF-1:xEu3+ samples were measured at room temperature. Excitation spectra were measured by monitoring 611 nm emission, corresponding to the 5D0 → 7F2 transition of Eu3+. The wavelength of the excitation light for the optical emission measurement is 393 nm. The luminescent decay curves were recorded at room temperature and 77 K.
elements.clean_text:
Measurement of Optical Spectra and Luminescence Decay Curves

Photoluminescence (PL) emission and excitation spectra were recorded using a Horiba FluoroMax-4 spectrophotometer equipped with a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. While measuring the spectra, both the excitation and emission splits were set at 0.6 nm; the working voltage of the photomultiplier tube was 700 V. The luminescent decay curves were recorded using a customized ultraviolet (UV) to mid-infrared steady-state laser and a phosphorescence lifetime spectrometer (FSP920-C, Edinburgh) equipped with a digital oscilloscope (TDS3052B, Tektronix) and a tunable midband optical parametric oscillator (OPO) pulse laser as the excitation source (410-2400 nm, 10 Hz, pulse width of 5 ns, Vibrant 355II, OPOTEK). The optical excitation and emission spectra of serial MOF-1:xEu3+ samples were measured at room temperature. Excitation spectra were measured by monitoring 611 nm emission, corresponding to the 5D0 → 7F2 transition of Eu3+. The wavelength of the excitation light for the optical emission measurement is 393 nm. The luminescent decay curves were recorded at room temperature and 77 K.

elements.content: Luminescence quenching experiment was conducted to investigate the detection ability of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ on cations. Ten milligrams of MOF-1:5%Eu3+ powder were ground and immersed into aqueous solution containing 20 ppm M­(NO3) x (5 mL, Mx+ = Na+, Mg2+, Ag+, Ca2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Al3+, Ni2+, Fe3+, and Pb2+) to form a MOF-1:5% Eu3+–Mx+ suspension. After 10 min of ultrasonic shaking, the powder was separated from the aqueous solution by centrifugation and dehydrated under vacuum at 80 °C for about 2 h. The optical emission spectrum of dehydrated powder sample was recorded using a Horiba FluoroMax-4 spectrophotometer with 393 nm light as excited source. The optical emission would become weak if there is luminescence quenching in a MOF-1:5% Eu3+–Mx+ system. The luminescence quenching experiment described above was performed at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Quenching Experiment

Luminescence quenching experiment was conducted to investigate the detection ability of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ on cations. Ten milligrams of MOF-1:5%Eu3+ powder were ground and immersed into aqueous solution containing 20 ppm M(NO3) x  (5 mL, Mx+ = Na+, Mg2+, Ag+, Ca2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Al3+, Ni2+, Fe3+, and Pb2+) to form a MOF-1:5% Eu3+-Mx+ suspension. After 10 min of ultrasonic shaking, the powder was separated from the aqueous solution by centrifugation and dehydrated under vacuum at 80 °C for about 2 h. The optical emission spectrum of dehydrated powder sample was recorded using a Horiba FluoroMax-4 spectrophotometer with 393 nm light as excited source. The optical emission would become weak if there is luminescence quenching in a MOF-1:5% Eu3+-Mx+ system. The luminescence quenching experiment described above was performed at room temperature.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction structural analysis indicate that MOF-1 crystallizes in trigonal space group P3c1. The asymmetric unit of MOF-1 consists of four Y3+ ions, two deprotonated BDC2– ligands, one carbonate radical, and four hydroxyl groups (a). As shown in b, the deprotonated BDC2– ligands in MOF-1 adopt two coordination modes, according to the different bond characteristics of carboxyl units. In the first mode, all the carboxyl units bond to four Y3+ ions using only bridging bidentate mode. However, in the second mode, the carboxyl units apply both bridging and chelating modes to bond four different Y3+ ions. Four crystallographic independent Y3+ ions can be classified into two groups based on their coordination numbers (Figure S3). For Y1, Y2, and Y3 ions fully occupied at 6d sites, they are all eight-coordinated but with different coordination environments. Y1 ion defined by six hydroxyl groups and two carboxyl radicals, Y2 ion is surrounded by five hydroxyl groups and three carboxyl radicals, and Y3 ion is completed by five hydroxyl groups, one bridging carboxyl radical, and one chelating carboxyl radicals. For Y4 ion located at 2c site with site occupancy factor of 0.33, it is coordinated by nine O atoms from three bridging carboxyl radicals and three chelating carboxyl groups from three different BDC2– ligands. More detailed coordination information of Y3+ ions is summarized and provided in Table S1. The carbonate radical exhibits a μ5-η1:η2:η2 mode to bond to five Y3+ ions (c). All hydroxyl groups apply the same μ3-mode to coordinate with Y3+ ions. The Y–O bond distances fall in the range of 2.251 to 2.577 Å. Interestingly, all Y3+ ions can be joined by carbonate radical and hydroxyl groups to form an infinite 2-dimensional (2-D) inorganic layer with thickness of 5.773 Å (measured between two polyhedra, d,e). Furthermore, the 2-D layers stack with each other in ab plane with an −ABAB– mode. The distance between two adjacent layers is about 15.545 Å. Finally, the deprotonated BDC2– ligands connect the adjacent layers through the coordination interactions between carboxyl groups and Y3+ ions, forming a 3-D inorganic–organic hybrid framework structure (f,g).

Results and Discussion

Structure Properties of Compound MOF-1 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction structural analysis indicate that MOF-1 crystallizes in trigonal space group P3c1. The asymmetric unit of MOF-1 consists of four Y3+ ions, two deprotonated BDC2- ligands, one carbonate radical, and four hydroxyl groups (a). As shown in b, the deprotonated BDC2- ligands in MOF-1 adopt two coordination modes, according to the different bond characteristics of carboxyl units. In the first mode, all the carboxyl units bond to four Y3+ ions using only bridging bidentate mode. However, in the second mode, the carboxyl units apply both bridging and chelating modes to bond four different Y3+ ions. Four crystallographic independent Y3+ ions can be classified into two groups based on their coordination numbers (Figure S3). For Y1, Y2, and Y3 ions fully occupied at 6d sites, they are all eight-coordinated but with different coordination environments. Y1 ion defined by six hydroxyl groups and two carboxyl radicals, Y2 ion is surrounded by five hydroxyl groups and three carboxyl radicals, and Y3 ion is completed by five hydroxyl groups, one bridging carboxyl radical, and one chelating carboxyl radicals. For Y4 ion located at 2c site with site occupancy factor of 0.33, it is coordinated by nine O atoms from three bridging carboxyl radicals and three chelating carboxyl groups from three different BDC2- ligands. More detailed coordination information of Y3+ ions is summarized and provided in Table S1. The carbonate radical exhibits a μ5-η1:η2:η2 mode to bond to five Y3+ ions (c). All hydroxyl groups apply the same μ3-mode to coordinate with Y3+ ions. The Y-O bond distances fall in the range of 2.251 to 2.577 Å. Interestingly, all Y3+ ions can be joined by carbonate radical and hydroxyl groups to form an infinite 2-dimensional (2-D) inorganic layer with thickness of 5.773 Å (measured between two polyhedra, d,e). Furthermore, the 2-D layers stack with each other in ab plane with an -ABAB- mode. The distance between two adjacent layers is about 15.545 Å. Finally, the deprotonated BDC2- ligands connect the adjacent layers through the coordination interactions between carboxyl groups and Y3+ ions, forming a 3-D inorganic-organic hybrid framework structure (f,g).

elements.content: From the point of view of crystal growth, the morphology formation of a single crystal is influenced by its microscopic structure as well as the environment of growth procedure. Usually, the structural symmetry and unit cell parameters play an essential role on the morphology of crystals that were grown from solutions without any restriction. For example, crystals grown by top seeded solution growth (TSSG) method or hydrothermal method can have their intrinsic crystallographic planes coexisting to form the surface, so crystal with a specific symmetry that is prepared by TSSG method usually have unique morphology. However, the appearance of a crystal grown in a deeply controlled system is always determined by the external conditions such as growth speed, rotation speed, and rotation direction. A well-known example is YVO4 single crystal grown by anisotropic heating floating zone method and Gd3Al5O12 single crystal grown by micro-pulling-down method, which are commercially available and are widely used in the field of optoelectronics. Generally, both crystals mentioned above are smooth, rod-like without any edge or angle because the nucleation and crystal growth are strongly restricted by the gas–liquid and solid–liquid interfaces. However, some crystallographic facets appear when the growth speed is very low during the shouldering process.
elements.clean_text:
Relationship between Microscopic Structure and Single Crystal Morphology

From the point of view of crystal growth, the morphology formation of a single crystal is influenced by its microscopic structure as well as the environment of growth procedure. Usually, the structural symmetry and unit cell parameters play an essential role on the morphology of crystals that were grown from solutions without any restriction. For example, crystals grown by top seeded solution growth (TSSG) method or hydrothermal method can have their intrinsic crystallographic planes coexisting to form the surface, so crystal with a specific symmetry that is prepared by TSSG method usually have unique morphology. However, the appearance of a crystal grown in a deeply controlled system is always determined by the external conditions such as growth speed, rotation speed, and rotation direction. A well-known example is YVO4 single crystal grown by anisotropic heating floating zone method and Gd3Al5O12 single crystal grown by micro-pulling-down method, which are commercially available and are widely used in the field of optoelectronics. Generally, both crystals mentioned above are smooth, rod-like without any edge or angle because the nucleation and crystal growth are strongly restricted by the gas-liquid and solid-liquid interfaces. However, some crystallographic facets appear when the growth speed is very low during the shouldering process.

elements.content: Although the “dark procedure” of solvothermal reaction in this study is hard to be revealed, the morphology of the solvothermal product can be predicted based on the basic structural information since there is rare restriction for the nucleation and crystal growth of MOF-1. Based on the basic theory of crystal growth and structural geometry, the periodic bond chains and atom packing velocity along different crystallographic direction determine the final morphology of this crystal. Thus, the simulated morphology of single crystal MOF-1 grown in a near free system is shown in , compared with the actual appearance recorded by SEM measurement. When we set the atom packing velocity along the a and c axes with same relation to interplanar spacing and ignore the chemical bond difference along different direction, the predicted shape of MOF-1 crystal is a hexagonal prism with planes (100), (100), (110), (110), (010), and (010) appearing as side faces and planes parallel to (001) as end faces, as shown in f. However, the actual shape of MOF-1 seems to be a hexagonal plate with a layered nature rather than a hexagonal prism, as shown in a–d. The difference between the actual morphology and the predicted one is most probably caused by the chemical bond difference along the a and c axes. The formation of an inorganic slab is dominated by the packing of Y, C, H, and O atoms, but regarding the Y–O polyhedra, carbonates and hydroxyls are the basic components of the slab parallel to the (001) plane. Besides these inorganic components, H3BDC molecules involve in the atom packing process along [001] direction, which makes the atom packing velocity along the c axis slower than predicted. So, the as-obtained MOF-1 crystal seems to be suppressed at both ends and turns to be a hexagonal plate.

elements.content: Eu3+ substitution for Y3+ does not change the phase of compound MOF-1. As exhibited in Figure S4, the powder XRD patterns of serial MOF-1:xEu3+ crystals are consistent with the simulated one, and even the substitution rate reaches up to 30%. With the increasing Eu3+ content, the diffraction peaks of MOF-1:xEu3+ crystal shift toward the smaller 2θ side, meaning that the unit cell of MOF-1 enlarges when Y3+ ions are partially replaced by Eu3+ ions. Besides the shift mentioned above, the nearly unchanged pattern structure displayed in Figure S4 indicates that the microstructure of MOF-1 rarely changes at the presence of Eu3+ ion.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Spectroscopy and Electronic Transition of MOF-1:Eu3+ Crystals

Eu3+ substitution for Y3+ does not change the phase of compound MOF-1. As exhibited in Figure S4, the powder XRD patterns of serial MOF-1:xEu3+ crystals are consistent with the simulated one, and even the substitution rate reaches up to 30%. With the increasing Eu3+ content, the diffraction peaks of MOF-1:xEu3+ crystal shift toward the smaller 2θ side, meaning that the unit cell of MOF-1 enlarges when Y3+ ions are partially replaced by Eu3+ ions. Besides the shift mentioned above, the nearly unchanged pattern structure displayed in Figure S4 indicates that the microstructure of MOF-1 rarely changes at the presence of Eu3+ ion.

elements.content: The optical excitation and emission spectra of all MOF-1:xEu3+ samples are same as each other, without regarding the optical intensity. For conciseness, the optical spectra of MOF-1:5%Eu3+ is displayed in a as a representative. The excitation spectrum consists of an intense broad band and some sharp peaks. The broad absorption band, ranging from 220 to 350 nm, is assigned to the charge transfer between active centers and the organic ligands, while the sharp peaks appeared during 350–500 nm is attributed to the absorption transitions of Eu3+ ion from ground state 7F0 to higher energy states such as 5D1,2,3,4, 5L6,7, and 5G2,3,4,5,6. Correspondingly, the luminescence spectrum comprises serial emission peaks attributing to radiative transitions from 5D0 to 7F J (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4) sublevels. Based on the optical excitation and emission spectra, the energy levels and possible electronic transitions of Eu3+ ion are derived and illustrated in b. Once pumped from ground 7F0 state by 393 nm light, Eu3+ ions in MOF-1 crystal will be excited to 5L6 energy level and then nonradiatively relaxed to the metastable 5D0 level through 5D3, 5D2, and 5D1. Furthermore, Eu3+ ions relax to the lower lying ground states 7F J (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, and 4) through a radiative way, during which the luminescence takes place. The dependence of optical emission intensity on Eu3+ concentration is revealed by c,d, from which one can find that the integrated intensity of optical emission increases monotonously with the enriching of Eu3+ in MOF-1, keeping the profile and structure of these emission spectra unchanged. Since the electronic transition behavior of Eu3+ is sensitive to the local crystal field circumstance, the optical spectroscopy properties of Eu3+ ion always reveal information about the lattice site where it occupies. The appearance of weak emission peaks assigned to 5D0 → 7F0, 7F3 transitions, which are both electric and magnetic forbidden in an ideal crystal field with an inversion symmetry, is an evidence of the inversion symmetry breaking of Eu3+ sites in MOF-1. This feature of Eu3+ optical spectroscopy is consistent with the structural property of this crystal. Furthermore, the asymmetry degree of Eu3+ sites is investigated by calculating the ratio of 5D0 → 7F2 emission intensity to that of 5D0 → 7F1 transition, which is also called the R value. Since the first transition is electric-dipole driven and its transition intensity is usually influenced by the symmetry of the local crystal field, while the latter transition is magnetic-dipole driven and its intensity is independent of the circumstance of the local crystal field, the value of R usually reflects the asymmetry degree of the Eu3+ site. As shown in d, the calculated values of R of serial MOF-1:xEu3+ crystal fall into the range of 3.42–3.89. Compared with some other Eu3+ containing inorganic or MOFs compounds, the R values of MOF-1:xEu3+ crystals are similar to that of LBSO:35% Eu3+, indicating that the local symmetry of the Eu3+ site breaks from an ideal one with inversion symmetry at a relatively large degree like that of the latter. However, the R value of MOF-1:xEu3+ crystal is nearly independent of the substitution ratio of Eu3+ ion, revealing that the introduction of Eu3+ into MOF-1 hardly changes the local symmetry of lattice site where the rare earth ions occupy, which is consistent with the result derived from phase analysis at the beginning of this section.

elements.content: The influence of crystal field on the optical spectroscopy properties of Eu3+ could be further investigated by Eu3+ electronic transition parameters such as radiative transition rates, radiative lifetime, quantum efficiency, and quantum transition intensities. Even though there are four kinds of lattice sites that are potentially occupied by Y3+/Eu3+ ion in MOF-1, implying that there are four possible active centers in the crystal lattice, the difference of local crystal field between them could be neglected from the point of view of optical spectroscopy. As shown in Figure S5, the luminescence decay curves of samples MOF-1:1%, 16%, and 30% Eu3+ could be fitted by a first-order exponential function with a correlation coefficient of 0.9861, 0.9951, and 0.9972. This fitting result demonstrates that the difference between these potential active centers is small enough, and they could be treated as one in the decaying time range from 0 to 1.4 ms at room temperature. The luminescence decay curve of sample MOF-1:1% Eu3+ measured at 77 K is displayed in Figure S6, and its luminescence lifetime is 1.421 ms, calculated by the following equation: τ̅ = ∫ 0 ∞ I ( t ) t d t ∫ 0 ∞ I ( t ) d t where I(t) is time-dependent luminescence intensity. It is well-known that there is no energy transfer between adjacent Eu3+ ions when the doping concentration is very low since the distance between them is large enough to avoid the electronic cloud overlap. Meanwhile, the phonon assist nonradiative procedure could also be effectively reduced at low temperature, regarding the large energy gap between 5D0 and 7F6 states (b). Therefore, it is rational that we treat the average luminescence lifetime of MOF-1:1% Eu3+ measured at 77 K as the intrinsic radiative lifetime of Eu3+. Then, the quantum efficiency η of serial MOF-1:xEu3+ samples could be obtained by calculating the ratio of radiative transition probability to total transition probability of the 5D0 state through ): η = A T / ( A T + A N ) = τ f / τ 0 where A T and A N are the probability of radiative and nonradiative transitions, respectively; τ f is the fluorescence lifetime measured at room temperature and τ 0 is the intrinsic radiative lifetime of Eu3+.

elements.content: The total radiative transitions probability from 5D0 to 7F J (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4) sublevels, A 5D0 , can be obtained by the reciprocal relation between A 5D0 and τ0: τ 0 = 1/A 5D0 . Meanwhile, the totally integrated intensity of the emission spectra I T of a specific sample is proportional to the total radiative transition rate A T, the relation of which could be described as follows: I T = a A 5 D 0 where a is a constant coefficient for the transitions from 5D0 to lower sublevels of the ground state in a specific sample of MOF-1:xEu3+. When the value of a is obtained, the radiative transition rate A J of each transition 5D0 → 7F J (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) could also be calculated using the relation: I J = a A J where I J is the integrated emission intensity of the corresponding transition. Using the relations listed above, we can obtain the total and single radiative rate from the 5D0 level to the lower lying sublevels. Then the luminescence branching ratio β J of transitions 5D0 → 7F J (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) could also be calculated using the relation β J = A J /A 5D0 . The Eu3+ concentration-dependent values of optical parameters discussed above are listed in , from which one can find that the radiative transition of Eu3+ from 5D0 to lower lying ground sublevels is dominated by 5D0 → 7F2. Meanwhile, the radiative transition branching ratios of each 5D0 → 7F J electronic transition is nearly independent of the Eu3+ concentration, which also demonstrates that the introduction of Eu3+ into MOF-1 hardly changes the microstructure of this compound. This result is consistent with that derived from the R value discussed above, whereas the quantum efficiency of MOF-1:xEu3+ decreases from 0.69 to 0.44 with the Eu3+ concentration increasing from 1% to 30%, most possibly caused by the enhancing of energy transfer between neighboring Eu3+ ions.

Based on the Judd–Ofelt theory, the quantum transition intensity parameters Ωλ could be calculated from the theoretical relation between A J and Ωλ described by the following expressions: A J → J ′ m d = 64 π 4 ν 3 3 h ( 2 J + 1 ) n 3 S m d A J → J ′ e d = 64 π 4 e 2 ν 3 3 h ( 2 J + 1 ) n ( n 2 + 2 ) 2 9 ∑ λ = 2 , 4 , 6 Ω λ ⟨ Ψ J ∥ U λ ∥ Ψ ′ J ′ ⟩ where J represents the original level of the radiative transition 5D0 and J′ is the terminal levels of the radiative transition 7F J (J = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4), ν is the wavelength number of the radiative transition, h is Planck’s constant which is equal to 6.626 × 10–27 erg·s, n is the refractive index of the matrix, e is the charge of an electron and is equal to 4.80 × 10–10 esu, 2J + 1 is the degeneracy of the initial state, S md is the magnetic dipole transition line strength, which is independent of the host and is equal to 7.83 × 10–42 (dimensionless), ⟨ Ψ J ∥ U λ ∥ Ψ ′ J ′ ⟩ is a reduced matrix element for J → J′ transition of Eu3+ ions. Since the intensity of magnetic dipole transition is independent of the crystal circumstance, the value of the refractive index n could be derived from the optical emission spectral parameters of transition 5D0 → 7F1. Then, the Judd–Ofelt intensity parameters Ωλ could be calculated utilizing the spectral parameters of transitions 5D0 → 7F2 and 5D0 → 7F4. The value of Ω6 are not calculated in this work because the emission of 5D0 → 7F6 is too weak to be detected. The calculation results of Judd–Ofelt parameters of serial MOF-1:xEu3+ crystals are displayed in , from which we can find that the values of Ω2,4 are not sensitive to the change of Eu3+ concentration. The similar distribution manner of Ω2,4 and R values demonstrates that the introduction of Eu3+ does not obviously modify the structure of MOF-1. Meanwhile, the value of Ω2 is a little smaller than that of NYW:Eu3+ and KLW:Eu3+ crystals but larger than that of YSO:1% Eu3+ and KGWP:Eu3+ crystals. As an indicator of structural symmetry, the value of Ω2 reflects the local structure symmetry of the lattice site where Eu3+ ion occupies. The higher the Ω2 value, the lower the local symmetry of the Eu3+ lattice site. So, it could be found that the local symmetry of Eu3+ ion in MOF-1 is higher than that of Eu3+ ion in NYW:Eu3+ and KLW:Eu3+ crystals but lower than that of Eu3+ ion in YSO:1% Eu3+ and KGWP:Eu3+ crystals.

The powder of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ was selected as representative to investigate the fluorescence response and selective probing ability of MOF-1 on metal ions in aqueous solution. At the beginning of a selective luminescence quenching experiment, 10 mg of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder was dispersed into 5 mL of aqueous solution that contains a cation (Fe3+, Na+, Mg2+, Mn2+, Cu2+, Ag+, Al3+, Ca2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Pb2+, or Fe2+) with concentration of 20 ppm, to form a suspension by an ultrasound method. The luminescent response of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder on these cations is shown in a, from which one can find that the luminescence of this powder quenches sharply after reaction with Fe3+. Meanwhile, the influence of existence of other cations in aqueous solution on the quenching effect of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders on Fe3+ was also studied. As revealed by b, the appearance of other cations hardly affects the luminescence quenching effect of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder on Fe3+ ion, indicating that this powder could be considered as Fe3+ probing material. For better understanding of the response of luminescence of these powders on Fe3+ ions, the luminescence titration experiment upon the addition of Fe­(NO3)3 to MOF-1:5% Eu3+ was further conducted. As presented in c, the emission intensity of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder that filtered from a Fe3+-containing aqueous solution declines gradually with the increase of Fe3+ concentration from 0 to 20 ppm. Quantitatively, this quenching effect can be rationalized by the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0 / I = 1 + K sv [ Q ] where K sv is the quenching constant, [Q] is the Fe3+ concentration, while the values I and I 0 are the luminescence intensities of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder filtrated from the aqueous solution with and without the addition of Fe3+, respectively. d describes the K sv fitting curve of the MOF-1:5% Eu3+–Fe3+ system. The luminescence quenching behavior of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder versus Fe3+ concentration in the range of 0–350 μM matches the Stern–Volmer model well, showing a good linear fit with R value of 0.976 and K sv value of 1.905 × 104. However, the limit of detection (LOD) of this system could also be calculated to be 12.7 μM based on the result obtained above, using the equation LOD = 3σ/K, where σ = 100 × (S/I 0), K is the slope between the luminescence intensity versus the Fe3+ concentration, and S is the standard deviation of the luminescence intensity measurement determined by the baseline measurement of blank samples. The detection ability of our powder on Fe3+ in aqueous solution, quantitatively estimated by the values of K sv and LOD, is comparable with that of some other luminescent MOFs probes such as Eu-HODA, EuL3, SUMOF-7II, and Eu3+@MIL-124.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Probing Property of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ Powders on Fe3+ 

Fluorescence Response and Selective Probing Ability of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ Powder on Fe3+ 

The powder of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ was selected as representative to investigate the fluorescence response and selective probing ability of MOF-1 on metal ions in aqueous solution. At the beginning of a selective luminescence quenching experiment, 10 mg of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder was dispersed into 5 mL of aqueous solution that contains a cation (Fe3+, Na+, Mg2+, Mn2+, Cu2+, Ag+, Al3+, Ca2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Pb2+, or Fe2+) with concentration of 20 ppm, to form a suspension by an ultrasound method. The luminescent response of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder on these cations is shown in a, from which one can find that the luminescence of this powder quenches sharply after reaction with Fe3+. Meanwhile, the influence of existence of other cations in aqueous solution on the quenching effect of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders on Fe3+ was also studied. As revealed by b, the appearance of other cations hardly affects the luminescence quenching effect of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder on Fe3+ ion, indicating that this powder could be considered as Fe3+ probing material. For better understanding of the response of luminescence of these powders on Fe3+ ions, the luminescence titration experiment upon the addition of Fe(NO3)3 to MOF-1:5% Eu3+ was further conducted. As presented in c, the emission intensity of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder that filtered from a Fe3+-containing aqueous solution declines gradually with the increase of Fe3+ concentration from 0 to 20 ppm. Quantitatively, this quenching effect can be rationalized by the Stern-Volmer equation:  7       I   0   / I = 1 +   K   sv    [ Q ]     where K sv is the quenching constant, [Q] is the Fe3+ concentration, while the values I and I 0 are the luminescence intensities of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder filtrated from the aqueous solution with and without the addition of Fe3+, respectively. d describes the K sv fitting curve of the MOF-1:5% Eu3+-Fe3+ system. The luminescence quenching behavior of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder versus Fe3+ concentration in the range of 0-350 μM matches the Stern-Volmer model well, showing a good linear fit with R value of 0.976 and K sv value of 1.905 × 104. However, the limit of detection (LOD) of this system could also be calculated to be 12.7 μM based on the result obtained above, using the equation LOD = 3σ/K, where σ = 100 × (S/I 0), K is the slope between the luminescence intensity versus the Fe3+ concentration, and S is the standard deviation of the luminescence intensity measurement determined by the baseline measurement of blank samples. The detection ability of our powder on Fe3+ in aqueous solution, quantitatively estimated by the values of K sv and LOD, is comparable with that of some other luminescent MOFs probes such as Eu-HODA, EuL3, SUMOF-7II, and Eu3+@MIL-124.

elements.content: To investigate the possible luminescence quenching mechanism of the MOF-1:5% Eu3+–Fe3+ system, the chemical elemental of the filtrate solution after luminescence probing experiment was analyzed using ICP-AES technique. It is found that Fe3+ ions in the aqueous solution are eliminated and that there is Re3+ (Re = Y, Eu) left in the filtrate after the luminescence quenching test. What’s more, the residual concentration of Re3+ ion in the filtration solution becomes larger when the initial Fe3+ concentration in the test solution increases, while the residual concentration of Fe3+ stays 0 if the reaction time is long enough, as shown in a. This phenomenon indicates that there is possible ion exchange between Fe3+ and Re3+ during the luminescence probing experiment. The dynamic evolution of Re3+ concentration in the filtrate and luminescence intensity evolution of the test MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders were also measured to verify the ion exchange between Fe3+ and Re3+. Ten milligrams of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders was ground and immersed into aqueous solutions containing 20 ppm Fe3+ and kept for ultrasonic shaking for 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, or 30 min, respectively. After centrifugation, the photoluminescence intensity of tested powder and residual Re3+ concentration in the filtrate were measured and shown in b. The luminescence intensity decreases gradually, while the residual concentration of Re3+ becomes larger over time, demonstrating that exchange between Re3+ and Fe3+ ions takes place during the luminescence probing experiments. As displayed by Figure S7, all the MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders keep their phase unchanged after the probing experiments, which also demonstrates that the ion exchange between Fe3+ and Re3+ exists. However, the UV–vis optical absorption property of the Fe3+-loaded MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder was also checked. As shown in c, there is rare overlap between the optical emission of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ and the optical absorption of Fe3+-loaded MOF-1:5% Eu3+. Meanwhile, the integrated optical emission intensity of 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1, 2, 4) electronic transition of Fe3+-loaded MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder was also studied as a function of initial Fe3+ concentration in the test aqueous solution. As shown in d, the intensity of each optical emission peak corresponding to 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1, 2, 4) transitions decreases simultaneously, keeping the luminescence branching ratios I 5 D0 → 7F J /I total nearly unchanged when the initial Fe3+ concentration in the test aqueous solution enlarges from 0 to 20 ppm. This demonstrates that there is rare energy transfer between Fe3+ and Eu3+ ions since the luminescence branching ratios of Eu3+ optical emission would change once energy transfer between Eu3+ and the target ion takes place during the luminescence quenching experiment. So, the chemical elemental analysis and optical spectroscopy investigation results confirm that the exchange between Fe3+ and Eu3+ is the most possible mechanism of luminescence quenching of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders when reacted with Fe3+ in aqueous solution.

Possible Mechanism for Selective Luminescence Quenching of MOF-1:5%Eu3+ at the Presence of Fe3+ 

To investigate the possible luminescence quenching mechanism of the MOF-1:5% Eu3+-Fe3+ system, the chemical elemental of the filtrate solution after luminescence probing experiment was analyzed using ICP-AES technique. It is found that Fe3+ ions in the aqueous solution are eliminated and that there is Re3+ (Re = Y, Eu) left in the filtrate after the luminescence quenching test. What's more, the residual concentration of Re3+ ion in the filtration solution becomes larger when the initial Fe3+ concentration in the test solution increases, while the residual concentration of Fe3+ stays 0 if the reaction time is long enough, as shown in a. This phenomenon indicates that there is possible ion exchange between Fe3+ and Re3+ during the luminescence probing experiment. The dynamic evolution of Re3+ concentration in the filtrate and luminescence intensity evolution of the test MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders were also measured to verify the ion exchange between Fe3+ and Re3+. Ten milligrams of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders was ground and immersed into aqueous solutions containing 20 ppm Fe3+ and kept for ultrasonic shaking for 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, or 30 min, respectively. After centrifugation, the photoluminescence intensity of tested powder and residual Re3+ concentration in the filtrate were measured and shown in b. The luminescence intensity decreases gradually, while the residual concentration of Re3+ becomes larger over time, demonstrating that exchange between Re3+ and Fe3+ ions takes place during the luminescence probing experiments. As displayed by Figure S7, all the MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders keep their phase unchanged after the probing experiments, which also demonstrates that the ion exchange between Fe3+ and Re3+ exists. However, the UV-vis optical absorption property of the Fe3+-loaded MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder was also checked. As shown in c, there is rare overlap between the optical emission of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ and the optical absorption of Fe3+-loaded MOF-1:5% Eu3+. Meanwhile, the integrated optical emission intensity of 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1, 2, 4) electronic transition of Fe3+-loaded MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder was also studied as a function of initial Fe3+ concentration in the test aqueous solution. As shown in d, the intensity of each optical emission peak corresponding to 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1, 2, 4) transitions decreases simultaneously, keeping the luminescence branching ratios I 5 D0 → 7F  J  /I  total  nearly unchanged when the initial Fe3+ concentration in the test aqueous solution enlarges from 0 to 20 ppm. This demonstrates that there is rare energy transfer between Fe3+ and Eu3+ ions since the luminescence branching ratios of Eu3+ optical emission would change once energy transfer between Eu3+ and the target ion takes place during the luminescence quenching experiment. So, the chemical elemental analysis and optical spectroscopy investigation results confirm that the exchange between Fe3+ and Eu3+ is the most possible mechanism of luminescence quenching of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powders when reacted with Fe3+ in aqueous solution.

elements.content: A new Y-based metal–organic framework compound, marked as MOF-1 in this Article, has been synthesized by the solvothermal method. This compound has an empirical formula of Y10C51O45H36 and crystallizes in a trigonal system with space group P3c1 and lattice parameters a = b = 12.8178(12) Å, c = 21.520(2) Å. There are four kinds of Y atoms coordinated by carbonates, hydroxyl, and carboxyl groups. The BDC ligands in this compound adopt two coordination modes, with carboxyl units displaying two coordination modes of bridging bidentate and chelating/bridging tridentate. Generally, the structure framework of MOF-1 is composed of inorganic slabs connected by BDC ligands, and the morphology of the solvothermal product turns to be a hexagonal plate with layer nature. Eu3+ ions are introduced into MOF-1 to make it optically active. MOF-1:xEu3+ powder has intensive optical emission when excited by 393 nm light. Because of the compact structure of the inorganic slabs containing Y–O polyhedra as the basic structural unit, the MOF-1:xEu3+ powder shows good luminescence property with quantum efficiency as high as 69% when the Eu3+ content is 1%. Based on the optical spectroscopy data, the electronic transition parameters such as quantum efficiency, radiative transition rate, luminescence branching ratio, and electronic transition intensity are calculated to investigate the electronic transition of Eu3+ in detail. It is worth mentioning that the Judd–Ofelt theory was used during this calculation procedure, the result of which shows that luminescent relaxation of Eu3+ in MOF-1 from 5D0 to the lower lying 7F J sublevels is dominated by the 5D0 → 7F2 transition with a radiative transition rate of 386.5 s–1 and a luminescence branching ratio of 0.55. The nearly independent quantum parameters on Eu3+ concentration reveal that the microcrystal field of MOF-1 is almost unchanged in the presence of Eu3+ ion. However, the MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder shows effective luminescent probing ability toward Fe3+ in aqueous solution with K sv and LOD values of 1.905 × 104 and 12.7 μM, respectively. Elemental analysis and optical spectroscopy studies reveal that there is ion exchange between Re3+ and Fe3+ in the aqueous solution, which is the most possible reason for the luminescence quenching of MOF-1:5% Eu3+–Fe3+ system.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A new Y-based metal-organic framework compound, marked as MOF-1 in this Article, has been synthesized by the solvothermal method. This compound has an empirical formula of Y10C51O45H36 and crystallizes in a trigonal system with space group P3c1 and lattice parameters a = b = 12.8178(12) Å, c = 21.520(2) Å. There are four kinds of Y atoms coordinated by carbonates, hydroxyl, and carboxyl groups. The BDC ligands in this compound adopt two coordination modes, with carboxyl units displaying two coordination modes of bridging bidentate and chelating/bridging tridentate. Generally, the structure framework of MOF-1 is composed of inorganic slabs connected by BDC ligands, and the morphology of the solvothermal product turns to be a hexagonal plate with layer nature. Eu3+ ions are introduced into MOF-1 to make it optically active. MOF-1:xEu3+ powder has intensive optical emission when excited by 393 nm light. Because of the compact structure of the inorganic slabs containing Y-O polyhedra as the basic structural unit, the MOF-1:xEu3+ powder shows good luminescence property with quantum efficiency as high as 69% when the Eu3+ content is 1%. Based on the optical spectroscopy data, the electronic transition parameters such as quantum efficiency, radiative transition rate, luminescence branching ratio, and electronic transition intensity are calculated to investigate the electronic transition of Eu3+ in detail. It is worth mentioning that the Judd-Ofelt theory was used during this calculation procedure, the result of which shows that luminescent relaxation of Eu3+ in MOF-1 from 5D0 to the lower lying 7F J  sublevels is dominated by the 5D0 → 7F2 transition with a radiative transition rate of 386.5 s-1 and a luminescence branching ratio of 0.55. The nearly independent quantum parameters on Eu3+ concentration reveal that the microcrystal field of MOF-1 is almost unchanged in the presence of Eu3+ ion. However, the MOF-1:5% Eu3+ powder shows effective luminescent probing ability toward Fe3+ in aqueous solution with K sv and LOD values of 1.905 × 104 and 12.7 μM, respectively. Elemental analysis and optical spectroscopy studies reveal that there is ion exchange between Re3+ and Fe3+ in the aqueous solution, which is the most possible reason for the luminescence quenching of MOF-1:5% Eu3+-Fe3+ system.

elements.content: In other words, a new Y-containing MOF, containing an inorganic slab as structural building unit, has been discovered. The Eu3+-substituted powder sample shows good luminescence and selective quenching on Fe3+ ion, making it a potential luminescence probing material for the latter. The concentration-dependent electronic transition parameters of Eu3+ are systematically studied in a MOF matrix for the first time, which opens a new field of application of the Judd–Ofelt theory and demonstrates that the Eu3+ in MOF-1 lattice is not only an environmental probing ion but also a structural probing ion.

The Eu3+-substituted powder sample shows good luminescence and selective quenching on Fe3+ ion, making it a potential luminescence probing material for the latter. The concentration-dependent electronic transition parameters of Eu3+ are systematically studied in a MOF matrix for the first time, which opens a new field of application of the Judd-Ofelt theory and demonstrates that the Eu3+ in MOF-1 lattice is not only an environmental probing ion but also a structural probing ion.

cln_elements.content:
Yttrium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (YCl3·6H2O, ≥99.99%), europium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (EuCl3·6H2O, ≥99.99%), and 1,4-dicarboxybenzene (H2BDC, ≥99%) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF, ≥99.5%) was purchased from Xilong Chemical Engineering Co., Ltd. Gadolinium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (GdCl3·6H2O, ≥99.99%) was purchased from Tianjin Fengyue Chemical Co., Ltd. Acetic acid sodium salt trihydrate (NaAc·3H2O, ≥99%) was purchased from Hengxing Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. A mixture of YCl3·6H2O (0.300 g, 1 mmol), NaAc·3H2O (0.204 g, 1.5 mmol), and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (0.166 g, 1 mmol) were added into the mixed solvent containing H2O (10 mL) and DMF (10 mL) and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Then, the mixture was transferred into a 25 mL autoclave with a stainless-steel cover and a Teflon liner to perform solvothermal reaction at 190 °C for 120 h, after which the autoclave was slowly cooled to room temperature in the furnace. Colorless hexagonal-plate-like crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.1919 g (85.91% based on Y). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for compound MOF-1: Y10C51O45H12 (2233.69), C 27.42, H 0.54; found, C 26.94, H 0.54. The Eu3+-substituted compound (MOF-1:Eu3+) was prepared according to the procedure described above, using EuCl3·6H2O as source of Eu3+ to partially replace Y3+ ion. Colorless hexagonal-plates-like crystals were obtained.

Luminescence Quenching Experiment

Luminescence quenching experiment was conducted to investigate the detection ability of MOF-1:5% Eu3+ on cations. Ten milligrams of MOF-1:5%Eu3+ powder were ground and immersed into aqueous solution containing 20 ppm M­(NO3) x (5 mL, Mx+ = Na+, Mg2+, Ag+, Ca2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Al3+, Ni2+, Fe3+, and Pb2+) to form a MOF-1:5% Eu3+–Mx+ suspension. After 10 min of ultrasonic shaking, the powder was separated from the aqueous solution by centrifugation and dehydrated under vacuum at 80 °C for about 2 h. The optical emission spectrum of dehydrated powder sample was recorded using a Horiba FluoroMax-4 spectrophotometer with 393 nm light as excited source. The optical emission would become weak if there is luminescence quenching in a MOF-1:5% Eu3+–Mx+ system. The luminescence quenching experiment described above was performed at room temperature.

cln_elements.content: A colorless hexagonal plate of MOF-1 crystal with dimensions of 0.0275 × 0.0275 × 0.01 mm3 was selected for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The diffraction data were collected on an Agilent Technologies SuperNova Dual Wavelength CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The diffraction data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by multiscan method. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 using the SHELX-97 program package. All atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The structure was also checked for possible missing symmetry with PLATON. Crystallographic data and structural refinements are summarized in . Generally, the compound MOF-1, empirically formulated by structural determination as Y10(C8H4O4)6(CO3)3(OH)12, crystallizes in a trigonal system with space group P3c1 and lattice parameters a = b = 12.8178(12) Å, c = 21.520(2) Å. The calculated density is 2.449 g/cm3. The solution results are listed in . CCDC 1901919 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
